results.title: The River
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of Agriculture and Pare Lorentz
results.brief_description: A classic documentary in the history of film, noted for its vivid imagery, outstanding musical score and verse commentary. The film traces life in the Mississippi River Valley during the past 150 years before the American Government legislated for flood control. A graphic portrayal of the consequences of sharecropping, soil degradation, unchecked soil erosion and flooding.

results.title: The Rival world
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit, Stuart Legg and Bert Haanstra
results.brief_description: Depicts the human struggle against hunger and sickness. Insects outnumber man by 50 million to one and are man’s rival for food. Man has interfered with the balance of nature and now can only come to terms with his rivals by using organised scientific methods of control. Examples are drawn from many parts of the world, including the desert locust in East Africa and the use of aircraft against them.

results.title: The Rising tide
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, James Beveridge and Jean Palardy
results.brief_description: Re-enacts the development of the important co-operative movement in the fishing villages of the Canadian Maritime provinces. In the Twenties, when nearly all the inhabitants were close to starvation, a Government Commission set about to remedy the situation and recommended the formation of co-operatives, with Government assistance. The film shows the benefits to the community of properly organized individual and group self-help.

results.title: The Rise of Parnassus Needy
results.creator_credit: Cartoon Films, Barclays Bank and Richard Taylor
results.brief_description: A lighthearted cartoon which details the unlikely career of Parnassus Needy, an impoverished poet, whose rise to success is due to the help given by his bank manager.

results.title: The Rise of nations in Europe
results.brief_description: Lists the pattern of national evolution in France as an example of the growth of nationalism in many European countries. Explains how the increasing importance of artisans and merchants, resulting from increased travel and better tools and manufacturing methods, helped to strengthen the position of the king; and how the greater wealth provided him with funds to carry on wars and create central services. Shows the famous people of the era and many of the critical struggles.

results.title: The Rise of nationalism in Southeast Asia
results.brief_description: Explains that the new nations of Southeast Asia are of critical importance in world history. Surveys the general conditions which give rise to nationalism in the Philippines, India, Pakistan, Ceylon, Indonesia, Burma, Vietnam and Malaya, and examines the problems confronting each of these nations on their road to maturity.

results.title: The Rise of Catherine the Great [DVD]
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, Korda-Toeplitz Productions, Alexander Korda, Ludovico Toeplitz and Paul Czinner
results.brief_description: This biographical drama loosely based on historical facts is set in mid-18th century Russia during the reign of the somewhat domineering and determined Empress Elisabeth (played by the wonderful Dame Flora Robson) who in her waning years sets out to arrange a marriage between her nephew and heir to the throne, Grand Duke Peter (Douglas Fairbanks Jnr) and a young German princess named Catherine (Elizabeth Bergner). It is not long, however, before Catherine discovers that her dearly betrothed is both unfaithful and madly insane and yet for all this, she remains devoted and true to him. But with the death of Empress Elisabeth, and Peter’s ascension to the throne, life becomes more unpredictable and precarious for Catherine as Peter’s mental health and behaviour becomes more unstable. Circumstances take control and eventually Catherine is forced to assume power. This is an interesting piece of filming for its time and the quality acting and lavish sets certainly add to its depth. Cast also includes Gerald Du Maurier, Irene Vanbrugh, Diana Napier. NB: Filmed in black and white, the visual quality is quite dark in some scenes and the soundtrack is scratchy but still worth viewing.

results.title: The Rise of big business
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Kenneth Vose
results.brief_description: Through a study of the values, aspirations and achievements of Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller and J.P. Morgan, the effect these men had on the growth of great business enterprises and the further effect those enterprises had on American society is shown. Life among coalminers and in the slums contrast with the lifestyle of the rich and show the direct relationship between the monopolistic practices, ruthless competition and expropriation, and the lives of the poor.

results.title: The Rise and fall of the Great Lakes
results.brief_description: A canoe journey through the beautiful areas of the Great Lakes, formed over 10,000 years ago over successive Ice Ages. This geological and ecological history of the Great Lakes is accompanied by narration in ballad form. Eventually, the advance of civilisation becomes obvious with bulldozers felling trees and pushing earth, huge dams, ocean-going ships, factory chimney’s belching smoke and the effects of waste pollution on the Lakes themselves.

results.title: The Rise and fall of Squizzy Taylor
results.brief_description: Sneak thief, racketeer, standover man and murderer. The story of Squizzy Taylor, Melbourne’s Public Enemy No.1 told through old newspaper cuttings, photos, newsreel and re-enactment.
